Interesting topics!

I learned so much in this course! One thing that I wish were different were that there were fewer readings per week. I feel like the readings connect very well to the course material but there were so many that I could never get through them all. The written assignments are incredibly challenging. I felt very accomplished after the first one considering this is not my area of expertise, however, they are very time consuming and very difficult to grapple with.
This was a very helpful class that provided a clear outline of political science topics that are relevant to the US healthcare landscape and outside countries as well.

I loved this course even though I am currently struggling to finish a group project! I was amazed by how all-encompassing this course was, and even though I had a background in the topics we discussed, I felt I learned a lot.

This class was OK. I don't like Mark's lecture style, especially because he usually has 1 correct answer he is looking for when he asks questions, instead of just students honest opinions, which makes it scary to participate in class because he may quickly dismiss your comment. I think there should be a way to exempt out of this class if you've taken a lot of political science classes before, as much of the material was repetitive. Having 3 person groups for the final paper does not feel fair, when other students can be in groups of 4 --- maybe try to address this?
The instructor is fantastic and provided excellent course materials as well as curated meaningful discussions.

Strengths - Mark is an amazing professor. The course material is very interesting and relevant. 

Weaknesses - Certain individuals tended to dominate discussions, which resulted in discussions not being as fruitful as they could be. The assignment prompts were too broad and convoluted.

Really a poor course. Not really sure what I learned, except to hear the opinions of one man. This should really be a discussion and introduction into topics and concepts, but rather was a survey of topics that interested Mark and his opinions on them. Very little actual political theory or practical application taught. Pretty disappointing class

Starts off great but gets sort of monotonous over time. Would be nice to have some classes structured differently, just to shake up the lecture format once in a while. Topics were interesting but could have used more examples, visual aids, pulling from current events, other forms of media, etc. Also, having part of your grade based on participation in a class with over 40 students is just unrealistic.
Provides a solid conceptual foundation in policy and politics in the US.

Strengths: conversational, engages student contributions
Weakness: opinions mostly covered from a liberal standpoint only

Excellent! Course provides an essential perspective on health policy that all MPH students should have. It provided an essential background on many aspects of governance I had not yet been exposed to in other courses.
wonderful. difficult to convey so much information but mark does a great job
Good
Easy to fall behind on readings, felt much more like a lecture than a student-led seminar as the syllabus suggests, topics are relevant to current events

Please please please let groups submit peer evaluations on the group project. The effort put into my final project was very unequal and I personally do not believe that everyone deserves the same grade.

Strengths: Fantastic lecture/discussion periods; engaging and rewarding projects
Weaknesses: Some of the readings felt outdated

A strength of this course is that it makes students very excited about politics and allows students to understand why health policy changes are so difficult to make in the United States. A weakness of this course is that it is pretty partisan in that Democrats are favored over Republicans. Republicans are almost made out to be the "bad guys" in the course. An improvement could be to make the course more neutral.

Strengths: a tour de force of the many topics around politics and policy that are relevant to health care. Up to date and relevant readings and discussions.
Weaknesses: While probably not possible, the option to write a policy memo over a chosen topic instead of an assigned one, potentially earlier in the semester would be interesting.
I thought this was an awesome course and I really liked that it was discussion based and that the class helped drive the course, but in the general direction Mark wanted.
Great course, but difficult assignments. Also a lot of readings, which are relatively outdated.

Mark is incredible in ways that I think some students taking their first governance course may have a hard time understanding. The course is wonderful and invaluable in learning about policy and change-making, and the only thing I would have changed about this class would be pushing for greater participation from peers.
Amazing course, my favorite of the semester.  Strengths are the teaching style and lectures. The assessments were difficult, hard-won, but doable.
This is exactly how I want every course to be organized. More time is spent learning the material through readings and lectures, than in completing assignments.

STRENGTHS
-- The course materials were well-organized, each unit with its outline and handouts. All the course readings were organized and available to download from Canvas easily.
-- The curriculum does a good job of covering the history, economics, and governmental aspects of healthcare in the U.S. 

WEAKNESSES
-- There were only 2 assignments. Student understanding builds up incrementally over time, not in a 2-week heroic push. Student work should thus be evaluated incrementally and over time, with multiple small assignments. 
-- I wish descriptions of things like the final project were written up and sent out farther in advance. Students have complicated schedules, and time management was difficult when I could not prepare more in advance.

Class was really good. Schlesinger is a very good and intelligent professor. I know some students would have preferred him to be more unbiased in the way he would speak about Repulicans, the south, etc. The policy briefs were challenging, but I felt like they were a good assessment of how we were grasping the material. Group essay was tough--especially on a complex topic like LTC and being limited to 15 pages.
Alot of material to read but super helpful for understanding the role of government institutions, the public, and special interest groups in health policy outcomes.

Amazing class as far as material and the professor is concerned. As someone who knows little about health policy but also found a lot of overlap between the classes talking about health economics, I found this class incredibly refreshing. I didn't love the assignments, but they were an interesting exercise and I do appreciate the effort Mark put into providing the necessary background information.
Strength: his knowledge base and feedback he gives to students
One of the best professors
Great lecturer!
He teaches very far to the left and doesn't even pretend to try to be unbiased.

Mark Schlesinger is brilliant. I have learned so much from him in this course. His teaching style is very organized...I like that he puts up an agenda on the board before every class so you can reference it at any point if you get lost. He is also encouraging and does a great job of trying to get the class to participate in the conversation.

Excellent professor - he has a great sense of humor and seamlessly pulls together complex themes in policy. I think his teaching could be even better if he worked a bit more to monitor implicit partisan biases that sometimes came through in the way he discussed politics, and if he made slightly shorter and clearer prompts for his assignments (prompts were several pages long and a bit confusing to decipher).

Mark is an amazing professor. I was always so in awe of the way he ran his lectures like a well-oiled machine. When a student would say something that was confusing or not quite correct, he would always find a way to tie it in or re-package it to related it back to the material.

Mark's teaching style to me feels unapproachable + boring. I'd learn better with lecture slides / another way to follow along the train of thought. Also, would be helpful to just be told facts, instead of long lists of different factors that may / may not impact a health policy phenomenon.
Dr. Schlesinger is by far the best professor I have had at Yale.
Mark has a wealth of knowledge and delivers his lectures in a very organized fashion.  And he really does end up learning everyone's name!
Mark is a great professor and lecturer! He makes the class incredibly engaging and insightful.

Lots of mansplaining of his opinion, and seemed uninterested in hearing dissenting thoughts. Incredibly partisan, and even as someone who leans very left, I found it distracting and hard to see his lectures without bias given his extreme partisan leanings. I would highly recommend he avoid the snide remarks about conservative political thought as it discredits his ability to teach political theory in an objective manner if it is clear he does not take seriously one side.

Professor Schlesinger is brilliant and very passionate. It can be hard to follow him talking straight for two hours, so it would be nice if he included more discussion or even just a current events video or something to break it up. He takes ages to get grades back to you, but when he does he includes extensive comments that I found very helpful regarding how to build better political arguments, etc.
Fantastic, insightful and caring.

Mark's teaching style is open-ended and makes student opinions feel welcome. From a didactic point of view, I would have appreciated more concrete information rather than only the seminar-style, conversation. Overall a fantastic professor, and I'm very pleased with the course.

Fantastic- we were all so impressed by his ability to just talk every class without using any notes or slides. He clearly had such a deep understanding of course material that translated extremely well through his teaching and assignments. I also appreciated his willingness to engage in conversations with students about course material during class which lead to deeper understandings for all.
very well informed and a wonderful professor!
Good
Prof. Schlesinger is an incredible knowledge bank, full of lively stories, historical facts, and thoughtful questions. It was a pleasure to be his student.

Mark is great! Very knowledgeable and genuinely cares about the topics and his students. Really like how the lectures were outlined each week, so that they were easier to follow. Also, the handouts supplemented what we were learning very well.

Professor Schlesinger is one of the most talents course conductors I have ever seen. Every class was well-structured, flowed nicely, had room for discussion, and still managed to conclude on time. Professor Schlesinger would benefit from posting the course-handouts online after lecture, and from reviewing the course syllabus to see where newer materials may be available.

Dr. Schlesinger is a "master of his trade." I truly to believe him to be one of the best policy professors in the nation. It was unbelievable to me how he had no power points and was able to lead a lecture based on an outline on the board. I loved his discussion-based style of teaching. A weakness is that he seemed pretty partisan towards Democrats. An improvement could be attempting to make the class a little more neutral.

Strengths: vast knowledge set of the topics, relevant research, and history of health politics
Weaknesses: the course has a liberal tilt, though at a school of public health this is not completely surprising. A suggestion for the future might be to not automatically assume malevolence by the Republican party, but rather explore financial repercussions or moral arguments.

Mark was awesome. You can tell he is really enthusiastic about the material and that he loves teaching. My only criticism is that the course was very one sided. Mark is very left and that was definitely the leaning of the class, but in terms of having a well rounded discussion, his far left lean made it challenging.
Great instructor! One of my favorites
Mark is one of the greatest teachers I have ever encountered. YSPH is lucky to have him, and this course is one of the best at Yale - if you do the readings, put in the effort, and contribute.
The MOST inspiring and skilled lecturer I have had at Yale.
Mark is a great lecturer! He provides some excellent feedback.

STRENGTHS
-- The professor is an excellent lecturer, organized and thoughtful, incorporating many sources and good evidence into his arguments. 
-- The professor gracefully encouraged classroom participation.
-- The professor was responsive to student input. 

WEAKNESSES
-- There was a lot of reading, with little accountability. I would have liked maybe 5 minutes each class to discuss 1 short reading that had been marked in advance for peer discussion in small groups. That would ensure that students keep up and engage with the reading. The class periods would have benefited from being broken up into more types of activities besides lecture.

Same as above--Schlesinger is a very good and intelligent professor. I appreciated how no matter how someone answered a question, you were never "shut down"--he would work with your answer. I know some students would have preferred him to be more unbiased in the way he would speak about Repulicans, the south, etc.
Mark is absolutely lovely. He knows the material like the back of his hand. He is very attentive and sensitive to student input and is always willing to meet.
Amazing in every way. I looked forward to his lectures every week and felt bad that I never read because the articles sounded very interesting.
Lots of readings but lectures help clarify a lot of it, the prompts an assignments are overwhelming and require a lot of thinking but Mark knows that and he grades appropriately.
Great intro to health politics
Its good very necessary for anyone interested in health policy.
Super left but interesting
This is a great course for people interested in health policy issues in the United States from a political science perspective. I learned a lot and enjoyed the class discussion.

I loved this course! However, I may not recommend it to those not interested in policy or who aren't in Health Policy due to the mental gymnastics required for the projects we are assigned. With that being said, I believe to be successful in public health regardless of the field, you need to understand how policy works. Furthermore, it was a great civics class, and I am afraid colleges and high schools are failing to provide a solid foundation of civics, so really, everyone should take this class to be a more informed voter and societal participant.
Good if you don't know much about health policy and how it is made. Shop the first class to see if you like Mark's lecture style though, because if you don't it'll be a long semester.
I would and have recommended this course to fellow students.
Excellent summary of relevant political dynamics.  More about the poltics and sociology than health care facts per se.
It's a great course to gain a deeper understanding of the implications and formation of health policy. Definitely recommend.
I would avoid it if possible, but unfortunately it is a requirement for many. This should definitely not be a required course as it is largely a waste of time

definitely recommend!

yes, take this course

The course reviews the history of the U.S. health care system, as well as recent developments. The material has a strong economics focus and the professor asks for simple statistical analysis in class (along the lines of which percentages are bigger than others, and why does that matter?). As someone with an Econ background, I very much appreciated this analytical perspective on policy and public opinion.
A class about the politics of health policy. I would definitely recommend it to another student. I feel more equipped to engage in these topics than I did before.
Take it! Even if you are not a health policy student, the information you learn from this course is very useful for any work in the US for public health.

Would recommend this class as a must for all students at YSPH regardless of concentration. Absolutely loved it. Essential to understanding why the American health care system is so messed up (from a politics pov).
